origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Center for Global and Intercultural Study.

did.unittitle: Center for Global and Intercultural Study (University of Michigan) Records 1964-2004, 1982-1996
did.abstract: Office that administered foreign travel and study programs the University of Michigan; records document administration of program, content of curriculum and student experience.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was transferred to the library in different accessions beginning in 1993. Donor no. 8099

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., University of Michigan Center for Global and Intercultural Study Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: In the 1960s, the University of Michigan College of Literature, Science and the Arts established and administered student overseas travel and study programs, including the Junior Year Abroad Program in Aix-en-Provence, France and Freiburg, Germany. In the early 1970s, the college centralized administration of the programs in the Center for Western European Studies (CWES), which received funding for this work from the Ford Foundation. By that time the programs included a joint program with Sarah Lawrence University in London, and the University of Michigan-University of Wisconsin Academic Year Program in Italy, which is situated in Florence. Funding from the Ford Foundation ended in 1977, and the college resumed financial support for the programs. Some university departments organized their own programs. The Romance Languages and Literatures department, for example, supervised two: one at the University of Salamanca in Spain and one at the University of Tours in France. All overseas travel and study programs were directed and staffed by senior faculty from Michigan or from the cooperating institutions.

In 1983, CWES was reorganized and given control over all international study programs, including those in departments. CWES established an executive committee as the agent to oversee operations, and four other committees to handle various tasks. The committees included: Foreign Study, International Exchange and Fellowships, On-campus Programs, and Colloquia and Conferences. The members of the executive committee included the director and associate director, a past director, and each of the four committee chairs. With this reorganization several new programs were inaugurated, including four in Britain, and one in Paris. The executive committee members in conjunction with the dean of the College of Literature, Science and the Arts appointed the CWES director who served a three-year term.

In 1989, the Office of International Programs (OIP) replaced the Center for Western European Studies as the overseeing agency for study abroad programs. The OIP was later replaced by the Center for Global and Intercultural Study (CGIS), which was founded in July 2009 to provide a wide variety of global engagement and learning opportunities to the University of Michigan Community. Today, the CGIS offers over 70 programs in over 30 countries, serving "students with diverse academic interests at international and domestic sites on every inhabited continent.
For current information on the Center for Global and Intercultural Study consult the unit's web page at the following url: http://www.lsa.umich.edu/cgis

arrangement.p: The record group is divided into five series: Background, Administrative Files, Programs, Correspondence, and Photographs.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Office of International Programs document the development and administration of the University of Michigan's travel abroad and foreign study programs and the content of the program at various sites, particularly Florence, Paris, Aix-en-Provence, London, and Freiburg. Records include committees minutes, correspondence, curricular records, syllabi and student evaluations of the program.

scopecontent.p: The Background series (1991-1997, 12 folders) provides a brief introduction to Center for Western European Studies (CWES) and OIP activities. These files include an outline of CWES' main areas of development since 1977, an administrative structure outline of CWES, and information and publicity materials compiled for students about the various OIP programs and about foreign study opportunities in general. This material is housed in boxes 1, 8, 13, and 19.

The Administrative Files series (1969-1997, 20 folders) includes files of different office committees. Within the minutes of meetings of the executive committee are discussions about establishing new programs and changing existing ones. There are also committee discussions of the nomination of new directors for the various programs and the work of the current staff. The files also include reports on individual programs, reports on faculty and staff, and proposals for establishing new programs and improving existing ones

did.unittitle: Report of the Committee for the Review of OIP 1991

scopecontent.p: The Programs series (1964-2004, 20 linear feet) is an alphabetical arrangement of files on the programs administered by CWES and OIP. The programs in Florence, Paris, Aix-en-Provence, London, and Freidburg comprise the bulk of this series, which is the largest series in the collection. Documents found include student orientation material, student evaluations of the programs, directors' reports, budgetary information, faculty reports, course descriptions and syllabi, meeting minutes, policy and procedure statements, faculty position descriptions, and general correspondence. General correspondence includes legal, fiscal and disciplinary action issues. This material is housed in boxes 1-7 and 9-22.

did.unittitle: Eastern and Central Europe (Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary) 1996-1997

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1977-1997, 40 folders) concerns the internal workings of the programs. Many of the letters are incoming and outgoing from the directors' or associate directors' office and detail aspects of operations and administrative matters. Also included are letters discussing potential joint programs with various institutions in the United States and abroad.

The Photographs series (undated, 3 folders) has nineteen black and white, 8" x 10" interior photographs of the Villa Boscobello, used as the residence in Florence for the University of Michigan - University of Wisconsin Academic Year Program in Italy. There is, in addition, a folder with seven black and white, 5" x 7" photographs of a student gathering in Aix-en-Provence.
